That is why we are seeing laws that poll at over 75% popular approval failing to even get a floor votes. Senators are afraid of getting a primary challenge.

Dear Silicon Valley,
Instead of stealing our data and making dumb stuff that is of negligible benefit to us as a society, perhaps one of you can invent the Personal Force Field? Clearly we will need them with these zealots on the Supreme Court running the show. 
Thanks,
A Citizen that remembers Newtown...and Parkland...and Columbine...and Las Vegas...and El Paso...and....

I remain very skeptical of the glib dismissal of the phrase “well regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free State” in the Heller case decision.  If, in fact, the founding fathers intended to declare that the Second Amendment protects an individual's right to possess firearms, unconnected with service in a militia, why would they mention a militia at all?  Or, why wouldn’t they have stated outright that the right to bear arms is also extended to the individual for personal use not related to a militia?  Why would they have had to justify the right to bear arms if they considered it a natural right?  How can it be that the adamant originalists considered that phrase, crafted specifically for inclusion in the constitution by the founder fathers, to be so inconsequential?  The justification that is based on traditional English law makes no sense because the Crown would certainly not have supported armament for insurrection. Antonin Scalia, who wrote the majority opinion, was an avid marksman and hunter and an inveterate egoist.  Perhaps he just wanted what he wanted and was willing to reframe that phrase to get it.  And perhaps that is why it remains so controversial.

The 2nd was ratified in 1787, ‘arms’ meant single shot muskets and pistols. People seldom died from being shot, they died from subsequent infection. To say that the 2nd anticipated today’s stock of arms is absurd. We have a ‘right’ to drive, if we pass a test, get a license, register every car we own, and buy insurance for each one. The same needs to apply to gun ownership.

Another example of an activist conservative SCOTUS looking to expand on previous rulings. Heller effectively upheld the Castle doctrine, a common law tenet that allowed for the protection of one’s (and one’ family) and property, but in so doing, created a glaring (although appropriate) exception to the clear & well understood meaning of the Second Amendment - what the Framers INTENDED the S/A to represent, and that clear intent withstood various challenges for 200  years.

Justice Scalia’s quote from Heller says it all, so in that sense, so long as the NYC and NYS laws allowed for issuance of concealed weapon licenses for those who could legitimately demonstrate a need to carry a PISTOL for protection, I don’t see where there’s any conflict with Heller.

What the NRA and anti-gun control forces are hoping for is a ruling that opens the floodgates for challenges against gun control measures enacted by many states - they’re not fooling anybody. But the even greater concern s/b that the logic being advanced by conservatives is going to be incorporated into arguments in favor of religious rights and against a woman’s right to choice - I don’t like the idea of Roberts acting as some sort of firewall.
SCOTUS has failed the 10th (limited federal powers) and 14th amendments (equal protection under the law).  Following our constitution has always been arbitrary.

They invite cases that suit their agenda by writing concurring or dissenting opinions that lay out their wish-list of cases they'd like to decide.  No doubt this comes from both wings of the court.

Under Roberts, the court is actually defining the game to be played and setting out the rules for argument to push their agenda.  And of course well-funded political movements are only too happy to invest in litigation to serve this agenda.

If the Supreme Court had any moral compass they would declare the second amendment redundant in the face of a standing Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, Coast Guard and multiple levels police forces and repeal it. But we all know that won’t happen for the next twenty years or more as long as Republicans hold the balance of power in the senate.

The “A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State” clause simply states the rational for the 2nd Amendment. The amendment’s author wanted to ensure that Americans possessed firearms so they could form militias and fight against tyranny, just as they did in 1776. The amendment does not say the “right of militiamen to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed,” which is what it would say if the intent had been to limit 2nd Amendment rights to members of militias. 

The 2nd Amendment says “the right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed.” The phrase “bear arms” means to “carry arms.” Prohibiting the carrying of arms outside households would be an infringement.

Felons can be deprived of their right to keep and bear arms because Section 2 of the 14th Amendment provides that the rights of citizens may be abridge due to participation in rebellion or other crimes. 

The danger in pretending that the 2nd Amendment doesn’t say what it clearly says is that we could pretend the entire Bill of Rights doesn’t say what it says. 

We need to let the people vote on whether the 2nd Amendment needs to be modified or repealed. An amendment that permits states but not the federal government to enact gun bans or gun control legislation might stand a chance of ratification. Why should Texans care if New Yorkers or Californians want to disarm themselves.

If the supreme court reenforces and strengthens the Heller opinion, they will have buckets of blood on their hands. Let them have whatever crazy laws people want in Wyoming but don’t shove them down the throats of citizens in large urban heavily populated areas where people want safety. We have a right to being safe and be protected by the rule of law and not guns.

Nothing has been done in the face of the horrific violence already inflicted and parents in every state send their kids to school with a brand of fear and dread no other generation of Americans has ever been made to endure.

It's laughable to think that this court will do anything but make things more bleak.

If the meaning of what the founders meant aligns with; "every citizen fit to serve in a martial capacity" then I'd be ok if gun owners were tested to be fit to serve every few years or so just as I have to re-new my drivers license. If Heller said "the Constitution guarantees an individual right to own guns — in the home, for self-defense" how does that translate into the right to roam the streets or country side with AK-47s and AR-15s?

Scalia took  "militia" out of the the Second Amendment. The "militia" was one half of the American fighting force in the Revolutionary War. There were no armories for the storage of war material at that time as a colony of England.
At the time there were those that were afraid of a standing army, and thought state "militias" were needed instead for defense purposes. Other concerns of the time are the father of the 3rd Amendment. Seems antiquated today, but was real to those who were wealthy in NY and NJ in 1789.
The "standing" army side won over the "militia" side due to the pragmatic issue of training and the constant threat of England in a few short years.
The right wing of the SCOTUS has hypocritically overlooked "originalism" and "textual" guides in interpretations when current right wing "ideology" demands rewriting of the Constitution in the Second Amendment cases. but uses those same  interpretations in support of right wing "ideology" decisions in other areas.

What a mess of unnecessarily complex and convoluted legal wrangling due to the fact that the Supreme Court did not originally seem to comprehend what “a well regulated militia” means. (That somehow got past “originalists” like Scalia who claim they believe the Constitution should be interpreted as written.)

There’s hope though. The 2nd Ammendment may eventually self destruct once every voter in the country has lost a loved one to a mass shooting, and we repeal it.

Maybe Anti-Constitutionalists should stop ginning-up laws that don't pass Constitutional muster?

Also, those commenters that truly believe that the NY "law" is reasonable can never again talk about how their opponents on the right are illogical and ideologically bound.

This country experiences a mass shooting, on average, every day!  No other country is so barbaric.  Yet we do nothing about it, and it seems the Supreme Court is prepared to make matters even worse.
I don't know what to say.

For all of its complaints about how state legislators have treated the second amendment in recent years, the Supreme Court has  failed spectacularly to provide any interpretation as to what the founders might have meant by a "well-regulated militia." The court now has blood on its hands. It can either continue to stick its collective heads in the sand or it can offer the country some much-needed guidance.

Fearing a Supreme Court loss, the New York legislature sought to repeal this law, hoping the Court would find the controversy moot.  I hope the Court does not do that.  New York's hostility to legal gun ownership is palpable.   If this case were dismissed, the Governor and Legislature would soon be at work coming up with something even more burdensome on legal gun ownership.

If you don't want your gun laws struck down, with the setting of unfavorable precedents in the process, perhaps it would be wiser to forget about these most draconian measures, and concentrate on those who actually use firearms in the commission of crimes.  And keeping guns out of the hands of the unfit, rather than the public at large.

Nowhere in the Second Amendment is ownership mentioned.  It says that members of a well regulated militia may "keep and bear arms".

The recent NRA/manufacturers/Supreme Court interpretation about near universal, mostly unregulated gun owning is not justified by the text or the intent of the original document.  

Mass shootings are a scourge foisted on us by the likes of Scalia and Thomas.

Nothing good can come of this. 

Something MUST be done about the SCOTUS. It no longer even remotely reflects the will of the people. 

One of the first acts of a new president should be to tackle a way to fix this travesty the GOP has set in place.

Even a cursory reading of the Second Amendment makes it clear that the individual citizen has a right to possess any form of MILITARY weapon whether that be an AK-47. rifle, or howitzer.  The right to on a pistol is less clear since the only military use of a pistol is to shoot soldiers ho disobey orders.

So the question that the Court will have to answer is just what does the Second Amendment protect?  Is it the traditional view that the right of the states to have militias that might oppose the federal government?  Or is it some new newfangled individual right to wage war on civilized society?

Certainly the traditional view was brought to  conclusion by the Civil War.  No state or group of states may wage war on the United States.  And if there was any doubt, then it was settled when President Eisenhower nationalized the National Guard to enforce Brown v. Bd of Ed.

Perhaps an interesting twist. The 2nd Amendment ensures the right to bear arms, not the right to purchase or self-build, nor modify.

It gives oversight to Congress with some organizational help from the states. They did not seem to grant ordinary citizens the right to own, modify, or build weapons, instead, they give the right to defend the United States, to bear arms, provided by Congress

What could be simpler?  "...the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed"?  Bear means carry, right?  

The only remedy is to repeal the Second Amendment.  That is also simple, and where progressives should be focusing all their effort.

In 1789 the right to bear arms as individuals for personal safety, hunting etc would have been taken as a given.  The 2nd Amendment was unnecessary from the point of view of individual rights. It was  a contrivance authored by a reluctant Madison at the urging of Henry and Mason who were concerned that the Federal government should not have control over the militias which were perceived as being essential to the security of a free state (that is to say, states worried about slave uprisings).  It is an anachronism, or should be. Individual states should have the power to regulate in accordance with their own circumstances taking into account the practical reality that getting rid of 350 million weapons is not remotely possible. Unfortunately the strict constructionists will probably rule that the right to "bear arms" extends to the streets and not just the home.
